Award.AwardTitle: Determining the Areal Extent and Tectonic Significance of Mesoproterozoic (1.50-1.45 Ga) Sedimentation and Metamorphism along the Yavapai-Mazatzal Lithospheric Boundary, New Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration:
Precambrian rocks in the western United States range in age from about 550 million years old to more than 2 billion years old and record the early tectonic processes and major geological events that created and changed the North American continent. Two recent detrital zircon geochronology studies in Precambrian rocks of Arizona and New Mexico have discovered that some of these rocks were deposited between about 1.45 and 1.5 Ga some 200 million years. younger than previously thought. These new findings require a significant reinterpretation about the tectonic evolution of the southwestern United States between about 1.7 and 1.4 Ga. This research project will conduct a detailed detrital zircon geochronology study of Precambrian metasedimentary rocks across central and northern New Mexico to help delineate the regional extent of these younger metasedimentary rocks and to better understanding the geometry of the depositional basin and the tectonic setting of the region at this time. Additional work will characterize the metamorphic history of these rocks using petrographic analysis, appropriate major element and trace element thermobarometry, equilibrium phase diagrams (pseudosections), and monazite geochronology to determine the pressure-temperature-time-deformation history and tectonic processes that followed deposition. The combined approach of detrital zircon geochronology and metamorphic monazite geochronology in the same rocks will constrain the maximum and minimum depositional age of these metasedimentary rocks. These new data will be used to test and refine tectonic models that describe how and when the continental lithosphere of the western United States was formed and how it evolved in the mid-Precambrian.

Preliminary data suggest that convergent, possibly accretionary tectonic processes may have occurred between 1.5 and 1.4 Ga. If additional data support this hypothesis, it would constitute a fundamental transformation in our understanding of the growth and tectonic evolution of North America. Undergraduate research and education is an essential component of this research project. This project will give undergraduate researchers experience with a major research initiative, the opportunity to travel to major research institutions and use cutting-edge research instrumentation, and develop critical analytical skills through data acquisition and interpretation. Undergraduate researchers will also gain experience presenting their results to the larger geological community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research is focused on understanding the formation and geological evolution of the continental crust in the southwestern United States between about 1.70 and 1.35 billion years ago (b.y.a.). Following deposition at the earth's surface, these sedimentary and volcanic rocks underwent burial into the earth's middle crust (10-20 km deep) and experienced metamorphism and deformation due to a mountain building (orogenic) event. Previously, these rocks were thought to have all been deposited about 1.7-1.65 (b.y.a.) and experienced significant contractional deformation and metamorphism at about 1.65 b.y.a., referred to as the Mazatzal Orogeny.

However, recent analyses of detrital zircon grains in metamorphosed sedimentary rock from both Arizona and New Mexico show that some of these rocks where not deposited until about 1.5-1.45 b.y.a. and are 200-250 million years younger than previously thought. These rocks still experienced burial and metamorphism at mid-crustal depths and this observation requires that there was a generally unrecognized mountain building event between about 1.45 and 1.36 b.y.a. (referred to as the Picuris Orogeny).

This project utilized U/Pb age dating of the minerals zircon and monazite to determine the age of sediment deposition and metamorphism in central and northern New Mexico and Arizona and the areal extent of these relatively younger (ca. 1.5-1.45 b.y.o.) metasedimentary and metavolcanic rocks and to determine a possible tectonic setting for the newly recognized Picuris Orogeny.

Over three years, field work was conducted in multiple mountain ranges of New Mexico including from north to south, Cedro Canyon, northern Taos Range, Picuris Mountains, near Guadalupita in the Rincon Mountains, the Rio Mora area, Thompson Peak in the southern Santa Fe Range, the northern Sandia Mountains and the southern Manzano Mountains. Samples and field observations were also collected from the Yankee Joe Group near Clay Springs, upper Salt River Canyon, Arizona.

Centimeter thick, metamorphosed volcanic ash layers were discovered near the base of both the Yankee Joe Group, near Clay Springs and the Trampas Group of the Picuris Mountains. Zircon recovered from these ash layers yield crystallization ages near 1480 Ma and represent the first reported metatuff ages reported for these rock sequences. These data show that deposition in Arizona and New Mexico occurred at about the same time interval and that sediment went from the surface to the middle crust in a relatively short time.

A second major discovery was the recovery of deformed, metarhyolite clasts from the Marquenas Formation, Picuris Mountains with zircon crystallization ages as young as about 1.45 b.y. This discovery shows that metarhyolite was forming at or near the earth's surface and was eroded into boulder–sized blocks that became incorporated into a boulder conglomerate at the base of the Marquenas Formation. Metamorphic monazite from this formation and from adjacent rocks in the Picuris Mountains shows that metamorphism of these rocks occurred between about 1.45 and 1.36 b.y.a. This close coincidence between the timing of metarhyolite crystallization and subsequent burial to midcrustal depths and metamorphism is striking and supports the interpretation of a tectonically active, orogenic setting.

Detrital zircon from all the field areas were analyzed to determine the zircon age populations and to gain insight into the sediment source areas. The younger metasedimentary rocks of the Trampas and Yankee Joe groups contain zircon with ages between about 1.5 and 1.6 b.y.o. and were possibly derived from a source rock in Australia and/or Antarctica. These rocks are confined to a relatively narrow zone in north-central New Mexico and extend to the southwest into Arizona where rocks with similar age detrital zircon populations have been recognized in the Clay Springs area, and other mountain ranges of Arizona. Older metasedimentay and metavolcanic rocks are observed both north and south of this zone and contain only zircon that are older than about 1.6 b.y.o..

Metamorphic monazite from all of the study areas yield U/Pb ages between about 1.45 and 1.36 b.y.o., consistent with a significant orogenic event that affected the southwestern United States. We propose that the regional map scale folding and penetrative regional foliations are to a large degree attributable to the Picuris Orogeny. This orogenic event may be due to a collisional tectonic setting or possibly more similar to a Sevier style orogenic event. Only one area in this study yielded older monazite with ages near 1.6 b.y.o. These are from greenschist facies rocks in the Manzano Mountains that did not experience the higher temperature regional metamorphic event associated with the Picuris Orogeny.

This award supported the developments of the scientific, technical and both written and oral communication skills of seven undergraduate researchers who conducted a significant part of the research describe in the above text. All students participated in fieldwork, sample preparation, data collection at major research institutions, data reduction and interpretation and all students presented the results of the research at national and local research conferences.
